content: I'm unable to easily remove the "binarity" of the output, but at least I could remove the "specific language advantage" by changing true/false to something else.

I think the problem statement is pretty clear, I understood with the first sentences only but maybe because "pointer" is a familiar notion for me. Maybe replacing pointer by index could be clearer for people who never used language with pointer
I would suggest not true/false output - what is the minimum number of values in array you need to change so that indexing process returns back to the first element of the list?
This is a less arbitrary version of my previously rejected submission. Let me know if the problem statement is still confusing: I will try my best to clarify it.

> Let me know if the problem statement is still confusing
If the statement contains "That sounds confusing" then it is confusing :p
The word "pointer" in particular is quite distracting and confusing, as it is usually associated with memory addresses and not just array indexes.

The examples clear it up perfectly of course, but having to figure out the requirements through examples instead of a simple statement is annoying, especially in "fastest" clashes. Concise, well-structured statement is important for those.
Examples should ideally be clearly separated from the main statement with something like a bold heading, so you know you can skip reading them, or at least skim across them knowing they won't have some crucial extra requirement sneaked in.

Take a list of N integers. Start at the first element (index 0) and repeatedly move following this rule: the value of the current element is the index of the next element you should move to. Will you ever return to the first element?

one. the answer is one element.  
just assign 0 to the first element, referencing itself. ;-)  

alternatively demand a minimum cycle length first

nonsense, the minimum is always 0 or 1, so its boolean again :p
change any of the visited indexes to 0. hell, change index 0 to 0.
I thought I needed to visit all elements and come back to first.
Your description is way better. Thank you.
